reviewText: (I shall take for granted that you are already familiar with season 1. This series is linear and MUST be watched in order for full enjoyment)This is not so much a sequel as a continuation of the adventures of everyone's favorite social climbers. Series 1 ended with a victory for Mapp and Lucia vowing revenge and series 2 begins with Mapp (now Mrs. Mapp-Flynt) returning from her honeymoon. Almost instantly, she and Lucia are back at each other's throats. In this series, politics are added to the mix with both Mapp and Lucia vying for a seat on the town council, Lucia making herself into a charitable saint and Mapp being as underhand as always.All of the actors from series 1 return (Lovely! I do not like it when shows change actors) Georgie is given more to do this time around. Actually, all of the characters are given more developement which should delight fans of the series.The series does not end conclusively. I won't give specifics, I'll just say that the social war is bound to continue for all eternity. What a shame there were no more installments into this lovely series.Once again, the costumes are madly original, the acting is all around superb and the writing is very good indeed.Anyone who enjoyed series 1 is bound to like this series too (though to what degree depends on their personal taste) and I suggest buying both series at once so that you are not left on a cliff-hanger.This is a wonderful series and I do hope it comes out on DVD soon. Anyone who loves clean, subtle humor with a twinge of madness would find this series very agreeable indeed. Essential for the anglophile.
summary: Round 2 of a delightfully catty social war

reviewText: Every bit as good as series one, series two simply picks up the balance of Benson's novels on Mapp and Lucia.  The only thing you do not see in this series are the two books out of Benson's six books which dealt with Mapp and Lucia as solo characters.  These would be "Lucia in London", which had no part for Mapp, and "Miss Mapp", which had no part for Lucia. This series is called "Mapp and Lucia" though which means that four of the six books are used, the ones where they appear together.  Dramatically this was a wise choice for a series as this whole series is built around the friction of Mapp and Lucia.We pick up where we left off and this sequence covers many choice scenes from the end books, such as Lucia and Georgie getting married, Lucia as the mayor of Tilling, Lucia's social climbing attempts on Poppy the Duchess, who is wild for Georgie and could care less about Lucia, Mapp's losing her house to Lucia when she doesn't follow Lucia's advice about her shares in a gold mine.When I was reading the books there were times when I really wanted to see certain things.  This series handles this aspect.  For example I was dying to see Quaint Irene's painting of Botticelli's "Venus" with Mapp substituted for Venus and the Major substituted for the North Wind.  It was great to finally see the painting and it was hilarious.  I also wanted to see what Mallards looked like as well as Grebe (the houses for Lucia and Mapp), what Tilling looked like, especially its relationship to the sea, what the costumes looked like (they were sensational), what Mrs. Wyse looked like traveling everywhere with her sables and car, what Mrs. Wyse's dead budgee looked like, etc., etc., I really feel sorry for the readers of these books who read them at the time they were written.  This means many of them never got to see the series since the series showed in the 1980s and the books were written fifty years earlier.i can also see why novels like this survive the test of time and so many others do not.  The books deal comically with human nature.  That is the same in 2010 as it was in 1930.  So the novels remain universal and as fresh today as they were eighty years ago.  Much of our fiction today will not pass this same test eighty years from now, especially the genre fiction.
Title: N/A

reviewText: If possible, the second series of 'Mapp and Lucia' is even better than its predecessor.  The success of the first seems to have given confidence to the filmmakers - there is a greater attention to the formal properties of the narrative - a more inventive use of music to comment on or undermine character and situation; a more meaningful use of visual composition.This, allied to the previously exquisite stylisation (the artificial sets in real locations; the mannered acting; the eye-popping costumes; the stacatto dialogue; the physical expressiveness and the choreography of movement; the rites and pageants; the plot rhythms) combine to create a startlingly modern work of pure artifice, whereby the bizarre wit and the tantalisingly accumulative stories achieve a Wildean pitch (is there a higher compliment?).This is a comedy of weird detail, excruciating emphasis and jarring juxtapositions, where every simper and twitch counts and reveals.  The last episode, 'Au Reservoir', where Lucia seems about to lose it all, and the narrative seems to fragment with her, is almost too painful to watch.  Or would be, if it wasn't so painfully funny.
summary: Does it really really have to end?
Title: N/A

reviewText: Mapp and Lucia was the well-mannered - (well at times well-mannered) but determined combatants of Tilling-on-the-Sea and at stake is nothing less than to crown of Queen Bee of TOTS!  Mapp has rules the tiny hamlet with an iron fist as lady of the village and has everyone dancing to her tune, until Lucia enters the pictures.  Recently widowed, Lucia has come to summer in Tilling-in-the-Sea.  Mapp has rented out her less than humble abode to Lucia, but still wants to hold control of the house and the village.  Lucia, however, sees as this as her chance to bring class to the tiny village of eccentrics.  A battle to the death - literally - well, almost.It's based on E.F. Benson's stories and is loving brought to life under the talented performance of Prunella Scales (Mrs. Fawlty in Fawlty Towers) as Lucia and Geraldine McEwan star as Mapp.In the second series, the gloves are off and this is a no holds barred battle for rule, as Tilling-on-the-Sea ain't big enough for the battling socialite mavens.It's Brit Com at it's very best.
summary: Mapp and Lucia continue the battle
Title: N/A

reviewText: MAPP AND LUCIA each spend an inordinate amount of time plotting ways to get themselves in the spotlight while casting the other in an unfavorable light.  This series is about as socially redeeming as JEEVES AND WOOSTER, however, watching it is like eating chocolate - you can't eat just one piece. Certainly, you won't find much of a moral to this series of tales, unless it is do unto others before they do unto you. In all likelihood, these stories like those of J&W; were used by the communists to demonstrate Western decadence.Lucia kills with kindness, doing what is best for Mapp despite Mapp's continuous rivaly and attempts to "best" Lucia. Lucia isn't really mean, but she is definitely capable of finding the perfect place to insert the rapier blade.  All in defense mind you as Mapp brings it on herself.  If she would just accept Lucia is her better all would be settled. Most of the townspeople have done just that, and that of course makes matters even worse, for Mapp was the big cheese before Lucia came to town.Mapp has tried everything from falsifying her knowledge of a foreign language to getting married in an effort to outshine Lucia. Lucia always manages to undo and outdo Mapp, however. The fun of course is feeling the frisson of fear that Lucia may be foiled, only to see how she cleverly foxes Mapp time and again. Usually, I am sympathetic for the underdog, which is clearly Mapp, but surprisingly, I don't feel sorry for Mapp.  Mapp usually hatches a plot to embarrass Lucia only to have it blow up in her face when Lucia turns the tables. Just how she will do this and how Lucia will react in each instance is the basis for the series. For example, if Mapp sells Lucia her disintegrating house located in a flood plain to Lucia, Lucia will probably find Roman ruins underneath and be featured as the house's owner in the Times of London.Lucia is supreme at turning lemons into lemonade revealing Mapp as the disgruntled looser she is.
summary: Better for you than a box of chocolates.....

reviewText: This is Deliciously played by three of my favorite actors. The expressions and dress and period are all so extra icing on the top of this delicious little cake of a romp. Everybody is over the top. Georgie's clothing is so special and the way he expresses our "Tarsome" things are tells you all you need to know about friends in the 30's in a small English seaside town. Their race for most popular lady patroness of the town is light hearted fun. I wish there were more than two season. The first episode is a little slow but it sets up so much and then once all are moved to the seaside town for the some and all the quaint Irene's of the town come out. Its a jolly good romp.
summary: Light humored Banter or is it "War" amongst friends.

reviewText: This televised series explores Edwardian England using E F Bensen's masterwork "Lucia" novels of social satire.  The books and series recount the "noble" efforts of Lucia and her wonderful henchman Georgie Pilson to gain Lucia her desired place in local society.  The videos give repeated pleasure and watching them "one more time" is like visiting a comfortably vicious world of social striving.  All of this is admirably transliterated to television in each one of the Mapp and Lucia series and no one stands out as better that another in this exceptionally faithful and vibrant effort to bring the joys of Bensen to new generations and to wider audiences. Each character is wonderfully realized: the hard-working 'climber,' Lucia is wonderfully acerbic.  The marginally upper-middle class Mapp is delightfully perfidious as she fights a rear-guard action under diminishing circumstances.  The parish vicar is clearly drawn in his efforts to avoid any controversy.  No effort has been spared in sets or costuming and the actor's performances endear them to all--the endlessly inventive way in which "Major Flint" expresses intoxication or the "spot on" way that "Godiva Plaistow" expresses her gossipy nature while retaining a pretty fair measure of common sense and a sense of fair play.  As foils for the major protagonists, Bensen offers portraits of genuinely wealthy and well-bred persons (Mr./Mrs. Wise)and of genuine 'artists' ('Quaint Irene'; 'Olga ***).  A good part of the adventure is the way that Georgie is drawn between the two lures of social posturing on one hand and developing his own genuine artistic and musical abilities on the other.Never mind my blathering:  order this wonderful series and buy the books!  Each and both of the mediums have meant a great deal to many people over the years since they first appeared.
summary: British Social Satire at its Televised Best

reviewText: The novels occupy such a hallowed place in the hearts of those who are devoted to Miss Mapp and Mrs Lucas that the non-initiated might look at these episodes and scarcely believe their eyes.  Arch, ridiculous characters prancing and preening across their screens, portrayed by respected and beloved British acting icons.  You might need to read the E F Benson novels (six in all) on which these discs are based.  Well, actually they're only based on three of the six; sadly, the Riseholme population is left out of these tales.  The costumes are amazing as is the camera work.  The performances perfectly capture the sublime nonchalance of Benson's characters.  Stupendous on all counts.
summary: Not Much To See, You Say?

reviewText: I first enjoyed Prunella Scales ("Mapp") in "Hobson's Choice" (1952!), and then again in "Fawlty Towers" with John Cleese. Geraldine McEwan ("Lucia") was a clever Miss Marple (2004-2007), endearing Miss Farnaby in Mulberry (1999) and Jean Brody in "The Prime of Miss Jean Brody" (1978). Both ladies have lovely, long lists of successful shows and films and are such fine seasoned actresses and excellent comediennes. This series is very enjoyable and worth watching and re-watching for the period costumes, lovely seaside village scenery, and pitch-perfect puns and barbs. Nigel Hawthorne is absolutely darling as Georgie Pillson and plays the "straight" man to Lucia's comic character, while embroidering, no less. This one is a keeper!

reviewText: These are two hilarious, poisonous women! What a great series, set in rural England in the 30's, showing the gamesmanship of small town social sets. Beautiful costuming, splendid acting, a total treat for remembering the mundane joys of unimportant social squabbling.

reviewText: This has to be one of the best series ever produced by the BBC and that is high praise indeed. E.F. Benson's books are perfectly realized in this series and the cast is perfect for this adaptation of the last three books in the series.Lucia is the main character of a series of books that Benson produced in the 20's and 30's. The first two books chronicle her efforts to retain her status as "Queen Lucia" in a village in the Cotswolds. In the fourth book, she goes on holiday to the village of Tilling (actually Rye, the home of Benson) after the death of her husband and meets her match in Elizabeth Mapp, a worthy foe in every respect. In the village of Tilling, Lucia meets her match (almost) and herein is the basis of the subsequent stories. It is this mix of the two that the series really takes off as both jocky for social influence while preserving a veneer of politeness.The books were popular in their day, but really took off when the BBC made the first series (also available in DVD). A great deal of humor rests in the ambitions of the characters and the situations that they find themselves in as a result. This second series, which is not as detailed as the first (it covered one book in six episodes, this covers the remaining books in the series in six episodes).While the production values are of the highest order and the script a delight, this series would have fallen flat if it wasn't for the superb cast. First there is Geraldine McEwan as Lucia, a part she was born to play. She uses her voice like a musical instrument, raising and lowering it to produce different comic effects. Anyone who sees the second episode where she keeps insisting that they must dig "deeper" will know what I mean. She really captures the invincible Lucia in all her intellectual pretensions and airs and graces.Second, there Prunella Scales. Known far and wide as Mrs. Basil Fawlty, she is excellent here as well. As always the comedic timing is wonderful. Watching her attempts to undercut Lucia continually frustrated is pure pleasure. I have seen her in other productions and I do not think that she is capable of giving a bad performance. She and McEwan and particularly good in the scenes that they play together.One other cast member is worth mentioning (although everyone associated with this production is nothing short of excellent)and that is Nigel Hawthorne. In the role of "Georgie," he really shines. One can appreciate Hawthorne's performance if one has seen him in other things, such as "The Madness of King George" and "Yes Minister."I can only hope that McEwan, Scales, Hawthorne and all the others associated with this production had as good a time making this series as they appear to have as we watch them hatch their plots and scheme their schemes in the village of Tilling.

reviewText: Not up to the quality of the first series (5 Stars). Storyline, acting and even makeup are all a little off when compared to the superb first set. Perhaps the gap of several years between shooting contributed to this. I can not see why the other customer reviews rate this series over the first set, which was rich with delightful characters and situations set against a  lush English seaside background. Nonetheless, Set 2, as is Set one,  is a "keeper", and a companion well worth having.

reviewText: Don't know how I missed this when it first came out, but discovered it on Amazon recently.  This is one of the best British comedies ever produced.  Perfectly cast, brilliantly acted - Nigel Hawthorne inhabits the character of  Georgie, and Geraldine McEwen is an appropriately over-the-top  Lucia (and her costumes are beautiful).  Perfect ensemble cast rounds out the rest of the characters.  I know some E.F.Benson purists object to Prunella Scales portrayal of Mapp, but I though she was great.  Treat yourself - especially since it's available for free streaming to Amazon Prime members.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This Series is a delightfully theatrical romp featuring three major British performers we have seen elsewhere.  Geraldine McEwan, who plays "Lucia," has recently been seen as "Miss Marple," and "Mapp" played by Prunella Scales was a star in the wildly popular "Faulty Towers" Series. And if you want a shock, Nigel Hawthorne plays an eccentric far and away from his portrayal in "The Maddness of King George."The "stories" center around the "English Village" and all the crazy goings on.  Gossip, jealousy, bickering and over the top humor are carried out by a cast of characters who all seem over the top."Exaggeration" is carried to the limit in costume, acting style and overblown storylines.  After a while, one just realizes this is not the typical series for simple clever narrative.  It is pure entertainment with a kick!  It is best to just sit back and enjoy the actors having a wild time with their "characters."  They seem to be having a ball with it so it is best to watch the ball roll!Thomas Lee Randleman
Title: N/A
